article.headline: Colorado 63, California 60
article.story: BERKELEY, Calif. (AP) -- After losing to one Pac-10 team last week, Colorado had a little extra incentive to beat California. Chris Copeland scored all 11 of his points after halftime and the Buffaloes rallied with a big second half to win at California for the first time in eight meetings, 63-60 on Tuesday night. "It was a message that we can be much better than we showed last game," Copeland said, referring to Colorado's 98-87 loss at Oregon State on Saturday. "It was a matter of opportunity. When it presented itself, I tried to capitalize, and I got some good looks." Richard Roby scored twice in the final 2:47 and also had a late steal for Colorado, sending the Golden Bears to their second narrow defeat at home in a week after a 73-72 loss to UNLV last Tuesday. Marcus Hall scored with 12.2 seconds left for the Buffaloes (3-2). Rod Benson had career highs of 25 points and 10 rebounds for the Bears, who missed several important shots in the final minute. Richard Midgley's 3 at the buzzer wasn't enough for Cal (4-3). Midgley finished with 14 points, but was 2-for-9 on 3-pointers against Colorado's tough zone defense. "I was running the baseline and struggling to find open looks today," he said. "We should have penetrated more. We've just got to finish games better. You've got to learn from it. It's just frustrating. We made key mistakes that cost us the game." It was the teams' second meeting in two seasons. The Buffaloes won 78-60 last season in Boulder, Colo., but Cal leads the series 9-7. Colorado last played in Haas Pavilion in 2000. Copeland played only three minutes in the first half, had two fouls and didn't score. He was one of several Colorado players to pick up their game in the second half. The 6-foot-8 forward is 10-for-14 from 3-point range so far this season after making all three of his tries Tuesday. The Buffaloes have five players averaging in double figures, and five scored more than 10 -- Copeland, Roby (11), Hall (12), Jayson Obazuaye (12) and Julius Ashby (11). Ashby also had a career-high 17 rebounds, including eight offensive as Colorado turned a 21-15 halftime rebounding disadvantage into a 38-32 edge. "If we keep a rebounding edge like we did in the first half I'm convinced we're going to get some good looks," Cal coach Ben Braun said. "That really hurt us. We have to do a better job." The Buffaloes made three 3-pointers during an 11-2 spurt early in the second half to get back in the game after getting just nine field goals and shooting 37.5 percent in the first half. Ashby's two free throws with 8:40 left gave Colorado a 47-44 lead, then DeVon Hardin answered with a three-point play to tie it. After Obazuaye made one of two free throws -- he got another try on his second attempt after a Cal lane violation -- freshman Eric Vierneisel made a 3 for a 50-48 Bears' lead. Hardin scored all six of his points in the second half and also had five rebounds as California concluded a three-game homestand. The Golden Bears used an 8-0 first-half run to take an early lead but struggled on offense. The Bears' poor 3-point shooting has plagued them all season, and they went 3-for-12 from long range Tuesday. "It's huge anytime you can come into a place like Cal and steal a win, and trust me, I believe we stole it," Colorado coach Ricardo Patton said. The Bears are down to eight healthy scholarship players after losing starting point guard Ayinde Ubaka to a broken left foot in an 82-63 win over Southern on Nov. 23. He is expected to be sidelined until mid-January. Cal is already without reigning Pac-10 Freshman of the Year Leon Powe, likely out for the season as he recovers from reconstructive knee surgery.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
